Situation1: Their parents directly open up about a personal struggle and look to them for comfort.
Expectation2: Be considerate with shared spaces and boundaries
Situation2: Trash pickup is tomorrow and the bins are only half-full with plenty of room left.
Story: I was sitting at the kitchen table, trying to finish my homework, when Mom sat down across from me. Her eyes were red, and she started talking about how overwhelmed she felt at work, how she didn’t know if she could keep up anymore. She looked at me, searching for comfort, and I could feel the weight of her sadness pressing on me. I wanted to be there for her, to listen and reassure her that things would get better. But just then, I remembered the trash bins outside. Tomorrow was pickup day, and our bin was only half-full. Last week, our neighbor Mrs. Lee had asked if she could use our extra space, since her family always had more trash than would fit in their own bin. She’d mentioned it again this morning, hoping I’d remember. I could see her through the window, dragging her heavy bag down the driveway. I felt torn—Mom needed me right now, but Mrs. Lee was counting on me to be a good neighbor. My heart pounded as I sat there, caught between being the child my mom needed and the neighbor Mrs. Lee hoped I’d be.
